Now if you could store that static charge in a capacitor and drain it off throw a resistor to a battery it would be a much better way to charge solar battery banks and could be converted to AC and put throw a transformer to supply the grid. the trick is to draw the static of miles of transmission lines that have no connection to ground. Back in the early days of Power line development the linesmen had to ground out Newly built Power lines not yet connected to the grid because they would build a static charge and linesmen would get killed from coming in to contact with a line so they started grounding the lines with giuide wires and chains at the very start of the job. Could this be Tesla's way of getting free energy? but back in tesla's day they didn't have the technology we have today with battery storage and resistive control of higher voltages. Static is low current high voltage but if you can lower the flow of the voltage using a resistor that would increase the current flow for a Battery bank and it would slow the time it took for the capacitor to discharge and could continue to produce current and voltage for days if not years even at night as long as their is air movement over the bare wires. Tesla didn't have IGBT transistors https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insulated-gate_bipolar_transistor to convert DC into AC wave form so it can be fed into a transformer and transfered to the public grid.

If you really want to see some super coolness touch it with a fluorescent tube (preferable something like a T8 standard 4 foot tube). If you are already holding the tube and the "jump" is only from the capacitor to the tube it will not hurt you. The pain felt by us from static discharge is the plasma created burning us when the electricity breaks down the airs dielectric resistance. Point is, you can light up a fluorescent light in your hand with nothing connecting it to anything except your body to ground. Works even better with a legit Van De Graff device. Enjoy!

Thank you SOOOOOOOOOOO much for egg knowledge Ing what did not work. It is interesting to see an end result, but I think we do a huge disservice to our science students when we do not show the perseverance it takes to get that result.

For instance, many people remember Edison for saying he had not failed, but rather knew 250 (or what other number gets inserted here) things that did not work. He had a wonderful result when he created a light bulb, but if we are to truly understand the genius of Edison, we have to know about those previous attempts where he experimented with something from his breakfast plate and even the bottom of his shoe after he had exhausted the obvious choices. Science is not just the results, it is the journey. The failures. The learning. The resolve to keep trying, and failing to eventually learn and get results.

Cool concept! Physics girl, you were having issues due to the shape of your capacitor. All sharp edges must be eliminated. The underside of the bottom half, compared to the top, is quite a sharp radius. Your charge is leaking off the bottom as it is charged up.

Jargony and misused words misused in science...

1. Theory.
2. "1000 times smaller" (ugh! You can't get more than 1x smaller because you have to divide to make something smaller, not multiply by whole numbers)
3. Light year. (it's a measure of distance, not time)

According to your setup, after initially charging your bowl, you have an excess of electrons in the bowl but not an excess in the plate, only a separation of charges there. After the spark you still have the same excess of electrons but now it is distributed between the bowl and the plate.
So I assume that after each spark you ground your capacitor to get rid of the excess electrons.
Similarly there would be a deficit of electrons on your charging pvc/cloth system, you would need to ground it too.

Great video as always. One thing I'd like you to please consider is that I find there's a recurring trend in your videos where you start off explaining each and every step very thoroughly, and then as you get closer and closer to the final point, your explanation of each step becomes less and less detailed until eventually, for some people, certain steps don't make any sense since we don't have background knowledge to be able to fill in the gaps. For example, you said, "the high voltage breaks down air." What does that even mean? You also said, "the charges leak through the air." What's happening when the charges are moving through the air? That spark is literally the entire point of this video and you didn't provide any animation or breakdown of what happens while the spark is being produced. All you gave that most critical moment is literally 1 second and 6 words (i.e. the charges leak through the air), yet you thoroughly explained and animated every step leading up to that.
I love watching your videos but I always leave feeling as if something was missing, as if I was introduced to a topic but it was not fully explained and I literally always have to go watch other videos on other channels to fully understand whatever your video was about.
